source.title: Thawing of human pluripotent stem cell (hPSC) lines:

source.description:
Thaw an aliquot of 1:10 diluted Geltrex
or in the fridge.

source.title: Thawing of human pluripotent stem cell (hPSC) lines:

source.description: Aspirate Geltrex and rinse the dish/plate 1x with an equal volume of DPBS.

source.body: Note: do not let the dish/plate dry out.

source.body: Note: the dish/plate is ready to receive cells for plating.

source.description: Take vial cells from liquid nitrogen to TC room on dry ice.

, and complete thaw by gently transferring pre-warmed hPSC culture media into the partially thawed cells.

source.description: Add and evenly distribute cells into dish/plate with pre-warmed hPSC culture media (from step 5).

source.title: Thawing of human pluripotent stem cell (hPSC) lines:

source.description: Transfer to incubator, cells should attach over a few hours.

source.title: Thawing of human pluripotent stem cell (hPSC) lines:

source.description: Change media the following day to StemFlex without Rock inhibitor.

source.body: Note: Withdrawal of Rock inhibitor will result in a notable change in morphology, from ‘spikey’ look cells with thin processes, to a smoother appearance. Some cell death may also occur.

source.description: Coat 6-well or 10 cm plates with Geltrex for differentiation as described above.
Nearly confluent hPSCs are dissociated and re-plated for differentiation

source.body: Note: Before induction of differentiation, hPSCs should lack obvious signs of differentiation or contamination, and be in a rapid growth phase.

source.description:
Aspirate culture medium and briefly and gently wash cells in
DPBS.

Add
TrypLE to cell culture,
per well in 6-well plate,
per 10 cm plate.

Incubate cell culture for
-
at
. After a 3 minute incubation, check to see if cells are detaching. Under a phase contrast microscope, the cells should start to round up and take on a phase-bright appearance, but not spontaneously detach from the plate. Once cultures adopt this appearance, gently suck up and dispel ~
with a P1000 pipette against the cells. They should easily dislodge and leave a small area devoid of cells. If cells do not dissociate easily, extend TrypLE digestion for another minute and repeat this test.

source.body: Note: Take care to avoid over-digestion, which can cause cell death.

source.description: Gently aspirate TrypLE.

To dissociate cells, add
/
for a well of a 6 well/10 cm plate, and gently pipette this medium over the plate to detach cells and dissociate them to a single-cell suspension.

Collect cells in 15 ml V-bottom polypropylene tube, and adjust volume with hPSC culture media (Total volume =
)

source.body: Note: This wash step dilutes residual TrypLE to slow further digestion.

source.description:
Spin at
for

at
. Aspirate supernatant, re-suspend cells in
.

for

at
. Aspirate supernatant, re-suspend cells in hPSC culture media

source.body: Note: These wash steps remove any remaining traces of TrypLE.

source.description: After re-suspending the cell pellet, adjust volume so that the suspension is visibly turbid, but not milky (approximately 1-5 x 106 cells/mL).

In a 1.5 mL polypropylene tube, mix
of this cell suspension with
, transfer
of that mixture onto cell counting slide. Count cells with automated cell counter

Plate cells onto Geltrex-coated plates in hPSC culture media at a concentration of 1 x 105 cells per cm2 (corresponding to 9.5 x 105 cells per well of a 6-well plate, or 5.5 x 106 cells per 10 cm plate). This density corresponds to approximately 80% confluence the following day. Ensure that cells are evenly distributed across the plate by gently shaking the plate left to right, then top to bottom before and after transferring it to the incubator.

source.body: Note: If cells are sparser, wait until cells reach the desired density before starting the differentiation. Sparse or over-confluent cells will not pattern well.

source.description:
If cells plated for differentiation are evenly distributed over the plate and at a density of approximately 75%, start differentiation by washing cultures once with DPBS and adding Day 0 (D0) medium (see below). Every second day, make full medium changes as follows (
-
per 6-well plate,
-
per 10 cm plate):

source.body: Note: Observe cells daily for changes in morphology. From Days 0-2, the culture should reach confluence and cells should have a simple and uniform hPSC-like morphology. By Day 4, cultures are highly compacted and cells adopt a more rounded appearance. Between Days 4 and 8, the cultures take on a dense neuro-epithelial morphology with identifiable neural ridge-like structures. A neuro-epithelial morphology is still evident before passaging on Day 14.

source.description:
Coat plates with Geltrex for maturation as described above (Optional: use a
final Geltrex concentration to facilitate neuronal attachment and long term culture).
On Day 15, neural progenitors generated above are dissociated and re-plated to encourage neurogenesis and neuronal survival and maturation.

source.body: Note: Plate cells based on different experiment requirements/layout.

source.description: Wash cells gently with DPBS.

Prepare a mixture of TrypLE and Papain by mixing
with 1 vial of Papain (140 U/vial). Papain aids in neuronal dissociation and will ensure significantly higher survival upon re-plating.

Add TrypLE with Papain to cells,
per well in 6 well plate,
per 10 cm plate.

Incubate cell culture for
-
at
. After
of incubation, check to see if cells are detaching. Under a phase contrast microscope, the cells should start to round up and take on a phase-bright appearance, but not spontaneously detach from the plate. Once cultures adopt this appearance, gently suck up and dispel ~
with a P1000 pipette against the cells. They should easily dislodge and leave a small area devoid of cells. If cells do not dissociate easily, extend TrypLE digestion for another minute and repeat this test.

source.body: Note: Take care to avoid over-digestion, which can cause cell death and release of genomic DNA.

source.description: Gently aspirate TrypLE and Papain solution.

To dissociate cells, add
/
for a well of a 6 well /10 cm plate, and gently pipette this medium over the plate to detach cells and dissociate them to a single-cell suspension.

Collect cells in 15 mL V-bottom polypropylene tube, and adjust volume with trituration medium (Total volume =
).

Spin at
for
-
. Aspirate supernatant, re-suspend cells in
.

Spin at
for
-
. Aspirate supernatant, re-suspend cells in desired volume of trituration medium to enable plating at the desired density.

In a 1.5 mL polypropylene tube, mix
with
, transfer
onto cell counting slide. Count cells with automated cell counter.

source.body: Note: If desired, cultures can be frozen at this point for later thawing as progenitors/immature neurons using the same procedure used for freezing hPSCs.

source.description: Plate cells onto Geltrex-coated plates in maturation media at a concentration of 1 x 105 cells per cm2 for cells maturing in N2B27 + BDNF (corresponding to 9.5 x 105 cells per well of a 6 well plate, or 5.5 x 106 cells per 10 cm plate)

source.body: Note: Plate cells at a density of 3 x 105 cells per cm2 for cells maturing in the enhanced maturation media, Synaptojuice (SJ1/SJ2).

source.description: On Day 16, aspirate medium and feed with N2B27 + BDNF or Synaptojuice 1 (SJ1).

On Day 17, aspirate medium and add twice the normal volume of Synaptojuice 1 (e.g.
per well of a 6 well plate,
per 10 cm plate) for neuronal maintenance for 1 week. This larger volume helps ensure that neurons are exposed to a relatively constant supply of nutrients. After 1 week, maintain the mature neurons on N2B27 + BDNF or Synptojuice 2 (SJ2).

Change
of media volume every second day.

source.title: Thawing of human pluripotent stem cell (hPSC) lines:

source.description: Dilute aliquot 1:10 in ice-cold DMEM/F12 to a final concentration of 1:100.
